did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: John P. Wodarski collection

repository.label: Location:
repository.corpname: Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: Monsignor John P. Wodarski collection is unique in terms of portraying and documenting activities of an ethnic Polish American parish and material related to the history of the Catholic Church and history of Poland. Msgr. John P. Wodarski was a pastor at the Holy Cross church in New Britain, Connecticut for several decades. Msgr. Wodarski was a very innovative priest who applied his ideas into educating the local community and always looked for ways to promote mutual understanding among other ethnic and religious groups. He was a great supporter of the Polish Studies Program at Central Connecticut State University where he served on the advisory board for many years. The collection includes documentation of the celebration of Poland's Millennium in 1966 and visit by Cardinal Karol Wojtyla from communist Poland to the US in 1969. Cardinal Wojtyla later became Pope John Paul II.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Monsignor John Paul Wodarski (1905-2002) was a long time pastor of the Holy Cross Catholic Church in New Britain, Connecticut. He was born on September 20, 1905 in Salem, MA. He was educated in catholic schools in Hartford and later attended St. Mary's College in Orchard Lake, MI and studied theology at the University of Fribourg, in Switzerland, where he was ordained to the priesthood in 1931. His first pastoral assignments from 1931 till 1944 were at St. Stanislaus in Bristol, St. Joseph in Willimantic and St. Mary in Putnam. Between 1944 and 1946 he was the US Army Chaplain. Msgr. Wodarski worked as director of Youth and CCD program in the Archdiocese of Hartford. He received the title of Monsignor in 1957 and became pastor of the Holy Cross church in New Britain in 1961, where he retired in 1992.

Msgr. Wodarski had extended interest in Polish affairs and history and in 1969 he helped to organize a visit to the United States of Cardinal Karol Wojtyla of Krakow, Poland who later became the Pope John Paul II. Msgr. Wodarski was an active member in many church, state and civic organizations and for his tireless work he received many awards and recognitions. His active involvements lead him to receive the doctorate Honoris Causa from Catholic University in Lublin in 1995 and from Central Connecticut State University (CCSU) in 1999. Msgr. Wodarski was a very active advocate for Polish cause and great supporter of the Polish Studies program at CCSU in New Britain. Monsignor John Wodarski died on October 12, 2002 and is buried at the Sacred Heart cemetery in New Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection includes personal papers, Polish American Priests Association records, other documents, clippings and correspondence related to Monsignor's activities and pastoral appointments. Collection includes also publications from the US and Poland related to the history of Catholic Church and Polish American issues on the national and local level.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: John P. Wodarski collection (CPAA 86-02). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

acqinfo.p: Majority of the material was donated in 1986 to the archives by Msgr. John P. Wodarski. Material dated after 1986 was send to the library every two to three years. Last donation of the material was made by Msgr. Wodarski's secretary after his death.

processinfo.p: Material donated in 1986 was processed by archivist Liz Savage. Material donated after 1988 was processed by Ewa Wolynska and Renata Vickrey.

list.item: For related material see the following collections:
Association of Polish Priests of Connecticut records, CPAA 86-03

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in the collection is arranged in eight series. Folders within each series are in chronological order:

list.item: Series I Personal and family related papers.
Series II Holy Cross Catholic Church.
Series III Association of Polish Priests of Connecticut (APPC).
Series IV Millennium of Poland's Christianity.
Series V Pope John Paul II.
Series VI Maximilian Kolbe Canonization and Beatification.
Series VII Rev. Boleslaw Kumor's writings.
Series VIII General - books, pamphlets, scrapbooks.

dsc.head: Container List
dsc.p: [The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection.]
